docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Planet Green) BIG RIVER MAN (2009) In April 2007 Martin Strel, above, a 52-year-old larger-than-life Slovenian with a fondness for horse-meat burgers, became the first person to swim the length of the Amazon, considered the world's most dangerous river. Mr. Strel -- a k a the Fish Man, a four-time world-record-holding endurance swimmer -- had already navigated the Mississippi, Danube, Paraná and Yangtze Rivers, braving blisters, sunburn, stomach illnesses, piranhas, anacondas, crocodiles and a parasitic fish in a quest to draw attention to the impact of pollution on these waterways. This latest documentary in the ''Reel Impact'' series follows Mr. Strel as he propels himself through more than 3,000 miles of the Amazon in 66 days to prove that one man can make a difference. John Maringouin directed. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Betty Rollins examines ''reverse missionaries'' from Nigeria, who are bringing their own brand of Christianity to the United States. Also, a profile of Charlene Wilson-Doffoney, an undertaker in Philadelphia, and an interview with Salam al-Marayati, executive director of the Muslim Public Affairs Council, about new airline security measures.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the widely anticipated introduction of a tablet computer at an event here on Wednesday morning, Apple may be giving the media industry a kind of time machine -- a chance to undo mistakes of the past. Almost all media companies have run aground in the Internet Age as they gave away their print and video content on the Web and watched paying customers drift away as a result.

docs.lead_paragraph: "Hope for Haiti Now," the download-only album of performances from the Haiti benefit telethon on Friday night, is No. 1 on this week's Billboard chart, outselling Susan Boyle, Lady Gaga and other hits by a wide margin despite being on sale for only part of the week. After going on sale through iTunes shortly before the show began on Friday, the album (released by MTV Networks, and for sale also through Amazon, Napster and Rhapsody) sold 171,000 copies in the United States through Sunday, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the first digital-only release to reach No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, and proceeds will benefit relief organizations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Brad Stone, David Carr, John Markoff and David Pogue were among journalists for The New York Times writing about the announcement of the iPad tablet computer by Apple's chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, on Wednesday. Here are excerpts from their observations, culled from the Bits blog, Pogue's Posts and their individual Twitter streams.

headline.main: Highlights from the Bits Blog Coverage of the iPad Announcement

docs.abstract: Highlights from Bits blog features comments on Apple's new iPad tablet computer (S)
docs.snippet: Brad Stone, David Carr, John Markoff and David Pogue were among journalists for The New York Times writing about the announcement of the iPad. Here are excerpts from their observations.

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of feverish speculation, Steven P. Jobs introduced Wednesday what Apple hopes will be the coolest device on the planet: a slender tablet computer called the iPad. For all the hoopla surrounding it, however, the question is whether the iPad can achieve anything close to the success of the iPhone, which transformed the cellphone and forced the industry to race to catch up.

headline.main: With Its Tablet, Apple Blurs Line Between Devices

docs.abstract: Steven Jobs introduces slender tablet computer called iPad, which Apple hopes will be its new coolest device; it is being positioned as pioneer in new genre of computing, somewhere between laptop and smartphone; iPad is half-inch thick and weighs 1-1/2 pounds and will vividly display books, newspapers, Web sites and videos on 9.7-inch touch screen; it is hailed as new era for publishing, as it gives media another way to sell content; device, which will be priced between $499 and $829, lacks some features common on laptops and phones; critics say it is little more than oversized iPod touch, pointing out that it lacks phone and cannot run Flash, software that handles video and animation on Web; also missing is alternative to AT&T data network, which is already buckling under strain of iPhone traffic; question surrounding rollout is whether iPad can achieve success of iPhone, which transformed cellphone and forced industry to play catch-up; photos (M)

headline.main: Amazon Pulls Macmillan Books Over E-Book Price Disagreement

docs.abstract: Amazon removed Macmillan books from its site in a dispute over prices of e-books.
docs.snippet: Amazon removed Macmillan books from its site in a dispute over prices of e-books.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amazon has pulled books published by Macmillan from its site in a disagreement between the online retailer and the publisher over the price of e-books. For the moment, Macmillan books are available on Amazon only when bought through third parties. Macmillan, like other publishers, has been wrangling with Amazon over the retailer's insistence that all e-books for its Kindle device be priced at $9.99. Many publishers want to charge more, or at least have more control over prices for individual books. The dispute hit a new level this week when Apple introduced its new iPad device, which will have an iBooks application through which publishers will have more control over e-book prices. The full story is here.

docs.lead_paragraph: Back in the old days, a sign that a corporation had hit the big time was when it got a single-letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Ford has ''F,'' AT&T has ''T'' (for telephone) and United States Steel has ''X.'' On the Web, there's another way a single letter can enhance a company's prestige. Go to Google's home page or browser toolbar and type a single letter into the search box. The search engine will then drop down a list of suggestions, based on overall search activity. There are 26 sites that have the distinction of being Google's first suggestion for each letter of the alphabet.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Amazon appeared to surrender to Macmillan in a dispute over the pricing of e-books. Macmillan, like other publishers, wanted more control over prices for their digital books. At first, Amazon responded by removing Macmillan titles, both digital and paper, from its site, except when bought through third-party vendors. Then, Amazon seemed to back down. But the talks are continuing, and Macmillan titles are still mostly absent from the Amazon site. Read the full story here.

docs.lead_paragraph: Look at the comments on the Amazon and Barnes & Noble Web sites if you want to know how some readers feel about the price of an e-book. The readers are used to $9.99, the price Amazon set when it introduced Kindle, and when they see an e-book costing more, or when an e-book's release is delayed while the far more expensive hardcover grabs up buyers -- well, you could fill a book with the grumbling. Readers are latecomers to the battle over digital price. Until recently, publishers and retailers have hashed it out, with publishers generally worried that $9.99 -- not a magic number but the one that managed to hook digital readers -- devalued books in readers' minds. Publishers gained back ground when Apple and Google indicated they were open to higher prices. Readers may have the last word.

docs.lead_paragraph: I'm bracing myself for comments about my Sunday column about religion. There's a tendency for liberals to devote lots of ink to decrying conservative Christians, because of their positions on social issues. I disagree strongly with typical evangelical positions on gay marriage, abortion, abstinence only education -- but I also think that liberals don't appreciate the impact of the arrival of evangelicals into humanitarian space or give sufficient credit for that change. The United States is doing far more for Africa today than a decade ago largely because evangelicals became a strong constituency for the Pepfar AIDS program and the PMI malaria program. Liberals were always in favor of such ventures, and what changed was that conservatives pushed for them as well -- and of course the Bush White House listened to them in a way it did not listen to liberals. And don't minimize those programs: Pepfar and PMI are saving millions of African lives.

headline.main: Your Comments on my Evangelicals Column

docs.abstract: A few more thoughts on evangelicals and Africa, as I brace myself for your comments.
docs.snippet: A few more thoughts on evangelicals and Africa, as I brace myself for your comments.

docs.lead_paragraph: Samsung unwrapped its long-awaited e-book reader for the American market this week, and it's a curious combination of useful features and an important missing feature. The $299 Samsung eReader E60 will lack 3G cellular capabilities when it ships this spring, a notable omission when compared with the current market leaders, the Kindle from Amazon and the Nook from Barnes & Noble, both of which are priced lower, at $259. The Samsung eReader will have Wi-Fi onboard for downloading content (the Nook also has Wi-Fi). The company is considering adding 3G in later editions, says Reid Sullivan, senior vice president of audio-video and digital imaging marketing at Samsung.

docs.lead_paragraph: Native Union has created a line of handset adapters for mobile phones that can't quite decide whether they are retro or futuristic. Either way, many people are likely to find its Moshi Moshi02 line an improvement over shouting into a tiny mobile phone. What the company has done is to take an old-fashioned landline handset, added a bit of Euro-design pizzazz, and adapted it so you can attach it a mobile phone. Because you can get the earpiece snug against your ear and the mouthpiece close to your mouth, you will find that you won't have to repeat yourself as often or shout to be heard.

Specialty sites included Ticketmaster, Avon (No. 15) and Netflix (No. 16). ProFlowers and its major competitor, FTD, which was ranked 21 with 514,000 transactions, had strong February sales because of Valentine's Day.

docs.lead_paragraph: For weeks, the pseudonymous reviewer known only as Historian had been using the British book site amazon.co.uk as his or her personal shooting gallery, taking aim at the authors of works on Russian culture and history: Rachel Polonsky's book "Molotov's Magic Lantern" was dismissed as "dense," "pretentious" and "the sort of book that makes you wonder why it was ever published"; and Robert Service's work was skewered as a "dull read" (for a book about Trotsky) and "rubbish" and "an awful book" (for a history of communism). Perhaps the only author to be spared the point pen of Historian was Orlando Figes, whose book "The Whisperers" was described as a "beautiful and necessary" account of Soviet history, written by someone with "superb storytelling skills" and of whom Historian said, "I hope he writes forever."

headline.main: No More Mystery Behind Savage History Reviews: The Author's Wife Did It

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (BBC America) TOP GEAR After buying used cars -- an FJ40 Toyota Land Cruiser, a Range Rover Classic, above, and a Suzuki Jimny -- over the Internet from dealers in Bolivia, James May, Jeremy Clarkson and Richard Hammond embark on a 1,000-mile drive from the middle of the Amazon rain forest to the Pacific coast of Chile through the treacherous terrain in the altiplano region, the Andes and the Atacama Desert. The ascent to La Paz along the steep North Yungas Road, popularly known as El Camino de la Muerte (''The Road of Death''), so terrifies the acrophobic Mr. May that he humorously threatens to cut off the head of anyone who bumps him. But he seems to be only half-kidding when he pulls a machete on Mr. Clarkson after a small accident. The two men leave their weapons behind when they appear on a special episode of ''Friday Night With Jonathan Ross'' at 9:40. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The guests include former President Bill Clinton and Jennifer Lopez. Here and on ''The View,'' at 11 a.m. on ABC, Alyssa Milano also promotes her new series, ''Romantically Challenged'' (Monday night at 9:30 on ABC), in which she plays a divorcée about to start dating for the first time since the Clinton administration.

docs.lead_paragraph: If you shoot a lot of video or snap huge amounts of RAW digital photos, you've probably heard about the SanDisk Ultra 64-gigabyte memory card. The card uses the new SDXC format, which will enable memory card makers to achieve huge capacities of up to 2 terabytes. For now, 64 gigabytes is the highest capacity card on the market. SanDisk sent me a loaner, and I put it through some real-world tests to evaluate its performance against other SD cards. The 64-gigabyte card costs $240 at Amazon, and that's not exactly an impulse buy. But is it worth it?

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (ESPN) STRAIGHT OUTTA L.A. In 1982 Al Davis, the principal owner of the Oakland Raiders, won an antitrust suit against the National Football League and moved his team to Los Angeles, capturing, in the process, a large number of black and Hispanic fans. Soon the newfangled Raiders were transformed into a brand as the team's silver and black colors and swagger became linked to the hip-hop scene in South Central Los Angeles, including the rap group N.W.A., of which Ice Cube was a member. In this documentary, part of ESPN's ''30 for 30'' anniversary celebration, Ice Cube, above, now an actor and filmmaker as well, looks at the culture clash between the football franchise and Tinseltown. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOLJamie Foxx tutors the four remaining singers: Crystal Bowersox, Michael Lynche, Casey James and Lee DeWyze.

docs.lead_paragraph: 7:23 p.m. | Updated Below The climate blogger Joe Romm and I agree (breaking news): Scientific research and assessments examining the link between human-driven climate change and malaria exposure have, for the most part, accurately gauged and conveyed the nature of the risk that warming could swell the ranks of people afflicted with this awful mosquito-borne disease. I did so last week in a piece on a new study in the journal Nature concluding that efforts to stem the disease are swamping the potential expansion of malaria endemicity from warming; he's done so today in a piece attacking those who chose to report on this news.

headline.main: More on Malaria in a Warming World

docs.abstract: More on the intersection of climate change and malaria risk.
docs.snippet: More on the intersection of climate change and malaria risk.

docs.lead_paragraph: Peter Max The psychedelic art guru Peter Max's 25,000-square-foot studio in New York City is part nightclub, part 19th-century salon. A D.J. spins fusion jazz records nonstop and luminous personalities are always dropping by -- not just arty types but astrophysicists like Michio Kaku and Neil deGrasse Tyson. At 72, Max is still wowed by the cosmos. ''Guess how many galaxies there are?'' he asks, giddily. ''About 350 billion!'' You can see some of that stardust sprinkled on this issue's ''T'' logo (''Tripping Out,'' Page 101). Born in Germany, Max lived a peripatetic youth, with stops in China, Israel, France and Africa. He first heard bebop on the radio in Shanghai. ''I just thought it was Chinese music.'' Max is now working on his first animated film, tentatively titled''You Can Trust a Universe That Creates Flowers.''

headline.main: Contributors

docs.lead_paragraph: Christopher Trela first discovered John Wilcock's long out-of-print "The Autobiography and Sex Life of Andy Warhol" while browsing a rare-book stall at a Fifth Avenue street fair in 1991. Wilcock, who was a travel reporter for The New York Times before becoming a founding editor of both The Village Voice and Interview magazine, visited the Factory for seven years, up to five times a week. Casual conversations with the likes of Leo Castelli, Ultra Violet, Charles Henri Ford and Lou Reed, culled at the height of Warhol's fame, eventually culminated in this oral history, which Wilcock self-published.

docs.lead_paragraph: No one epitomizes the pursuit of barbecue like my father-in-law. John's DVR is half-full of barbecue-related cooking shows, and he spends hours reading online commentary on proper smoking techniques. He uses natural gas when he's in a hurry, and charcoal when he's got all day, and can discuss the benefits of each. His esteem for the Weber brand is akin to another demographic's feelings for Apple -- that is, he believes it's not just the best, but that it has no credible competition.

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine you're the hero in one of those old movies, desperately lost in a windswept desert, undulating dunes stretching to the horizon. Out of water, tongue parched and skin blistered, you drop to your knees. Vultures circle overhead. (O.K., maybe you're in a comic strip, not a movie.) Yet there, in the distance, is a crystal blue pool - no, wait, dozens of them - and you push forward, fantasizing about diving in, slaking your thirst, soothing your miserably sunburned skin. It's a mirage, of course. Dozens of perfect blue pools don't just magically appear in the desert.

docs.lead_paragraph: Knock, Knock. Who's there? Apple TV? Apple TV who? In September 2006, Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, announced news of the company's latest offering: the Apple TV. Mr. Jobs had high hopes for his latest creation, so high that he told his audience that he hoped the Apple TV would be a fourth leg to the Apple business among PCs and iPods and iPhones. When the Apple TV was unveiled a few months later in early 2007, Mr. Jobs reiterated these comments in an interview with USA Today:We've got two strong legs on our chair today - we have the Mac business, which is a $10 billion business, and music, our iPod and iTunes business, which is $10 billion. We hope the iPhone is the third leg on our chair, and maybe one day Apple TV will be the fourth leg.Yet it wasn't long before Apple downgraded its hopes of a living room accessory and fourth leg to its business, and Mr. Jobs started referring to the poor Apple TV as a ''hobby.''

docs.lead_paragraph: In a case study we've just published, Elizabeth Olson writes about a culture clash involving Coca-Cola and Honest Tea. Not long after Coke invested in Honest Tea -- a small, entrepreneurial maker of organic teas and kids juices -- executives with the multinational noticed that the smaller company's packaging featured the phrase "no high fructose corn syrup." The executives construed the phrase as an implicit rebuke of Coke products. "We got a strong request to change the wording," said Seth Goldman, co-founder and chief executive of Honest Tea.

headline.main: Can Honest Tea Take Coke's Money and Keep Its Own Culture?

docs.lead_paragraph: The biofuel concept: If you just burn plant materials, you put out a lot of bad pollutants. But if you heat the materials in a container without oxygen ("pyrolysis"), you leave most of the carbon as "biochar," which makes an excellent soil additive (in fact Amazon Indians built up rich soils over hundreds of years using biochar). The gas that is given off by pyrolysis can be processed into clean-burning fuel. All of which sounds great, but skeptics point out that Africa is a prime target for biofuel land grabs, which destroy small farms and forest preserves. Hence the importance of using agricultural residues like corn cobs, and researching the impact.

headline.main: A New Approach to Biofuel in Africa

docs.lead_paragraph: I led an hour-long onstage discussion last week with two conservationists at the Aspen Ideas Festival exploring ways to manage human development to keep the Amazon rain forest thriving in this century. The core questions there now are the same as they were in 1989 and 1990, when I was lucky enough to crisscross the Brazilian portion of that vast river basin for months researching my book on the murder of the forest defender Chico Mendes.

headline.main: Can the Amazon Thrive in the 21st Century?

docs.abstract: A look at whether roads, dams and oil extraction can coexist with thriving rain forests.
docs.snippet: A look at whether roads, dams and oil extraction can coexist with thriving rain forests.

docs.lead_paragraph: For decades, logging has eaten away at the Brazilian Amazon, often called the "earth's lungs" for its ability to generate vast amounts of oxygen through photosynthesis. Experts estimate that roughly 20 percent of the rain forest has been destroyed, with much of it turned into ranchland or farms. Other primeval forests around the world, from Indonesia to Cameroon, are similarly threatened.

headline.main: Is the Tide Turning on Deforestation?

docs.abstract: Signs are growing that international efforts to clamp down on illegal logging and strengthen timber harvesting regulations are succeeding in slowing the destruction of rain forests.
docs.snippet: Signs are growing that international efforts to clamp down on illegal logging and strengthen timber harvesting regulations are succeeding in slowing the destruction of rain forests.

While other manufacturers strive to make their headsets smaller and less obtrusive, Etymotic has gone in the other direction. Opting for function, the EtyBlu2 includes a boom mic that wraps around the face, ending in a foam windscreen, tempting onlookers to shout, ''Operators now standing by!'' The result is both desirable, and not. People I called said my voice was very clear, although they could still tell I was on a mobile phone. Another advantage is you won't have to yell to be heard, and therefore don't have to share your conversation with everyone on the bus.

docs.lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (TLC) DC CUPCAKES Wielding only their grandmother's recipe, the sisters Sophie LaMontagne (above right) and Katherine Kallinis (left) gave up careers in fashion and private equity and dug into their life savings to open Georgetown Cupcake, a Washington bakery. Soon their concoctions -- like chocolate ganache cake with sunshine frosting, topped with a fondant flower -- had generated a large following. This six-part series follows the women as they prepare to take their local business national, starting with the creation of a Mardi Gras mask made of 1,000 cupcakes for a fund-raiser. At 10:30 the sisters lend their support to an animal rescue organization by turning their confections into a life-size dog centerpiece. They also devise a treat for dogs that they call pupcakes. 8 P.M. (HGTV) THE OUTDOOR ROOM WITH JAMIE DURIE A family in Van Nuys, Calif., asks Mr. Durie to help create backyard privacy. The catch: He can't touch the majestic tree in the center of the yard. After visiting a winter lodge in Jackson Hole, Wyo., Mr. Durie constructs a carved-wood pavilion with large stone pillars and conversation benches, surrounded by forest plants, cobblestones and a high-tech hot tub next to a bar.

docs.lead_paragraph: Lou Gold, a longtime commenter who lives in the Brazilian portion of the Amazon basin, is an invaluable member of the worldwide Dot Earth community (people from more than 200 countries have visited the blog). Gold posted a series of comments following the Amazon piece, and has consolidated them with a post on his blog, Visionshare. You can read the full post below.

The 500-gigabyte Clickfree C2N costs $180 (it's $142 at Amazon), and that's definitely a premium over standard 2.5-inch 500-gigabyte external drives, which sell for $120 or less. But the C2N can be a truly digital-life-saving device for those who can't commit to regular backups.

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't forget the authors. Last week it was the big book publisher and the big literary agent who sparred over who gets to make e-books out of titles that were published before there were such things. Now the Authors Guild has weighed in - with an eye on digital royalty rates for the writers it represents. In a letter to its members on Monday, the Guild said that publishers were largely to blame for the dispute between Random House and the literary agent Andrew Wylie, which came to a head last week when Mr. Wylie announced that he would begin his own venture to sell e-book rights for older books directly to Amazon, bypassing traditional publishers that already released the books in print and have staked a claim to the e-book rights as well. Random House responded on Thursday by saying it would not do business with the Wylie Agency until the situation was resolved.

headline.main: Authors Guild Weighs in on E-Books

headline.print_headline: Breakthrough Award For New Novelist

docs.lead_paragraph: With the publication this week of his first novel, "Bill Warrington's Last Chance," James P. King, 55, is living the dream of every hopeful writer who persists at his work despite rejection slips from publishing houses and agents. After Mr. King, who lives in Wilton, Conn., won the Amazon Breakthrough Novel Award, in which more than 6,500 writers from 22 countries competed, his novel, a road story in which an elderly veteran who is developing Alzheimer's disease travels across the country with his rebellious 14-year-old granddaughter, was acquired by Viking. "This is what reading is about, and what a good book is supposed to do," the mystery writer Sue Grafton writes in a blurb for the novel, Mr. King's fourth attempt at fiction.

headline.main: Breakthrough Award for New Novelist

docs.abstract: James P. King has won the Amazon award.

docs.lead_paragraph: Charles Yu's first novel, "How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe," was reviewed for us this past weekend by Ander Monson, who called it "a complex, brainy, genre-hopping joyride of a story, far more than the sum of its component parts." He also compared the book (narrated by a time-machine repairman who lives with a virtual dog and a neurotic piece of software) to the work of Douglas Adams. "Like Adams," Monson wrote, Yu is "very funny, usually proportional to the wildness of his inventions."

docs.lead_paragraph: A COMPANY MAN In 2008, when Kim Jones was named the creative director of Alfred Dunhill, the fashion establishment responded with a resounding ''Huh?'' Jones, as The Times of London put it, was ''more club kid than clubman.'' He loved big sneakers, loud prints, hip-hop and a wee bit of bling. He cavorted with Kate Moss, Lily Allen and Kanye West. He made neckties out of puffy nylon and once stamped black circles onto a model's nipples. Sure, he had bona fides -- Central Saint Martins, stints at Louis Vuitton and Hugo Boss. But this was Dunhill, a Jermyn Street staple, a heritage brand. Cathy Horyn, the New York Times fashion critic, was less than enthusiastic about Jones's first efforts, but after a tentative start he has consistently garnered raves. The British Fashion Council has awarded him men's-wear designer of of the year twice -- both as an independent designer and, in 2009, for his work at Dunhill. ''It's a beautiful brand, but it was sort of a sleeping beauty,'' says the 31-year-old Jones, whose eclectic edge has given the house a wake-up call.

headline.main: Profile In Style: Kim Jones

docs.lead_paragraph: In an article in Monday's New York Times, ''Search Takes a Social Turn,'' Jenna Wortham details how turning to friends for product recommendations is the latest rage in the Web world, with a growing number of companies trying to capitalize on the trend and bring such information to product searches. For instance, as she described in the article, users of Facebook can choose to see their friends' favorite books on Amazon, specify in their profiles what products they like and informally poll friends on Facebook or Twitter for product recommendations. The article also details some downsides of plain old reviews online, including reliability issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: Left, Yucaipa, via Bloomberg; right, Alex Brandon/Associated Press Ronald W. Burkle, left, and Stephen Riggio, the vice chairman of Barnes & Noble, are locked in a proxy struggle over the direction of the company. Leonard S. Riggio, the pugnacious Barnes & Noble chairman, may be in the fight of his career, but he says he doesn't relish it. ''I find it almost repulsive I have to be put in a position to defend myself,'' Mr. Riggio said last week in Barnes & Noble's corporate offices, leaning forward to press his point. ''I don't want to consume myself with not liking people.'' Just over a week before Barnes & Noble shareholders convene for their annual meeting, Mr. Riggio remains locked in battle with the billionaire investor Ronald W. Burkle over three board seats, including Mr. Riggio's. And Barnes & Noble has begun seeking potential buyers for the entire 1,350-store chain. Mr. Riggio, 69, lights up when talking about walking into physical bookstores or building up his company's digital one. It is his vision for the company that is at the center of the increasingly fierce proxy fight, one that began last month and in which both sides have recently dredged through the other's corporate history for purported instances of self-dealing and incompetence. This week Barnes & Noble is hoping to win the backing of Institutional Shareholder Services, an influential company whose advice on proxy fights is closely followed by corporate investors. Barnes & Noble has already won the qualified support of a smaller adviser, Glass Lewis & Company. The fight over Barnes & Noble may seem disproportionate to what is at stake. The company's market value has shrunk to less than $1 billion, and bookselling has been squeezed by Amazon.com on one end and Wal-Mart Stores on the other. But as Mr. Riggio says, the battle touches on deep reservoirs of sentiment about an empire he fashioned starting with a small bookstore 39 years ago. ''Lots of people have an emotional stake in books,'' he said. ''It's not like what they have with their haberdashers.'' For his part, Mr. Burkle has praised Mr. Riggio's accomplishments in building up Barnes & Noble and professes a desire for peace with his longtime acquaintance. But he also described Mr. Riggio as intolerant of questions about his strategy and management. ''With Len, you're either a white hat or a black hat,'' Mr. Burkle said in an interview by phone from his plane. Mr. Burkle said he was not seeking control of the company through the proxy fight, but wanted to have independent directors on the board. ''I want someone in there who doesn't say, 'That's the most amazing thing I ever heard' every time Len opens his mouth,'' he said. Mr. Riggio's biggest challenge remains grappling with the Internet, and he argues that digital bookselling is the biggest opportunity since the paperback revolution. Barnes & Noble's e-reader, the Nook, has been making headway in sales, he said. (The company says it controls about 20 percent of the e-book market, based on information from publishers.) He also pointed to growth at the company, which reported net income of $36.7 million on a 31 percent gain in revenue, to $5.8 billion, for the year ended May 1. For its most recent quarter, Barnes & Noble reported a 21 percent jump in overall revenue, to $1.4 billion, though it posted a $63 million net loss as a result of the legal fight with Mr. Burkle and weakening sales of print books. Many analysts and industry executives do not share Mr. Riggio's optimism. Shares in the company have tumbled 28.9 percent in the last year. An analyst at Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch downgraded Barnes & Noble to ''underperform'' last week, arguing that the company's digital strategy faced major challenges from wealthier rivals like Amazon and Apple. Mr. Burkle, who amassed his fortune in supermarket chains, alarmed Barnes & Noble when his investment company, Yucaipa, began buying up shares last year, acquiring a nearly 20 percent stake. He described Mr. Riggio's strategy as too little, too late. Adding to Mr. Riggio's anxiety were the near-simultaneous share purchases made by Aletheia Research and Management, an investment firm based in California that has often followed in Mr. Burkle's footsteps. To the company's management, Yucaipa and Aletheia's moves represented a potential stealth takeover of Barnes & Noble without a premium for shareholders. Mr. Burkle has denied working in concert with Aletheia. Glass Lewis and Mr. Riggio have questioned Mr. Burkle's lack of an alternative vision for Barnes & Noble. When pressed, Mr. Burkle says he has ideas for the company, but adds that because he is not seeking outright control of Barnes & Noble he sees no need to share them publicly. In the last two weeks, the clashes have become more personal, with Barnes & Noble and Yucaipa trading blows over past business decisions. Barnes & Noble published a 26-page compendium last week of what it described as examples of Mr. Burkle's having gained control of companies without paying a premium or making disastrous business decisions. One involved a series of transactions by Source Interlink, a media and distribution company created from Yucaipa-instigated deals, and in which Mr. Riggio was an investor; the company filed for bankruptcy in 2008. Another involved the merger of Pathmark and the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, a union that Barnes & Noble said resulted in gains for Yucaipa far beyond those realized by other shareholders. Mr. Burkle called the 26-page document misleading or inaccurate and pointed to several deals made by Barnes & Noble for companies in which the Riggio family had ownership interests. Chief among those, Mr. Burkle said, was the $514 million deal last year for a college bookstore business owned by Mr. Riggio and his wife. (Excluding cash held by the college unit, the deal amounted to $439 million, or about 3.8 times its profits.) The acquisition led to a spate of investor lawsuits, which are still pending. Glass Lewis has questioned Barnes & Noble's past pay practices, arguing that the company drastically overpaid its executives in light of its stock performance. Barnes & Noble's new chief executive, William Lynch, is paid $900,000 in salary, while his predecessor, Stephen Riggio, who was also vice chairman, was paid $800,000. Stephen, Mr. Riggio's younger brother, remains vice chairman and now earns $400,000. Mr. Riggio - who reduced his salary this year to $100,000 from $300,000 - made no apologies for what he said were necessary costs for hiring good executives. ''I'm significantly undercompensated,'' he said. ''Steve is undercompensated.'' Mr. Burkle has raised questions about whether Barnes & Noble's plan to sell itself will be fair and open to any bidder besides Mr. Riggio, who has indicated that he may make an offer. About 20 parties, including private equity firms, have either signed nondisclosure agreements with Barnes & Noble or are close to doing so, people with direct knowledge of the process said, adding that preliminary offers could be due as soon as next month. Yucaipa has not signed an agreement, Mr. Burkle said, arguing that such documents typically contain onerous restrictions for potential bidders. Dismissing concerns that the sale process was being handled improperly, Mr. Riggio said, ''If there's any stink to the process, it'd be all over the Street.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

docs.lead_paragraph: Are you being followed online? If you've ever used the Flash program from Adobe to watch videos - and odds are you have - you may have code on your computer that tracks your Web browsing, sending that information to companies that may sell it or use it for tailored advertising. On this week's Tech Talk podcast from The New York Times, Bettina Edelstein talks to Tanzina Vega, a Times media reporter, about so-called Flash cookies, which have raised privacy concerns and prompted lawsuits from consumers against companies involved in this form of tracking.

(NBC) COMMUNITY School's back in session at Greendale Community College, and -- who else? -- Betty White, above, shows up in a guest role as an esteemed but batty anthropology professor in this Season 2 premiere. Meanwhile Señor Chang (Ken Jeong) decides to enroll as a student so he can join the study group. The fifth-season premiere of ''30 Rock,'' at 8:30, finds Jack (Alec Baldwin) determined to help Liz (Tina Fey) hold on to a man for once by meddling in her relationship with Carol (Matt Damon). Elsewhere, Tracy (Tracy Morgan) agonizes over the termination of Kenneth (Jack McBrayer) as a page. And Jenna (Jane Krakowski) becomes the newest TGS producer. In ''The Office,'' at 9, Steve Carell begins his seventh and final season as Michael, who incites outrage when he refuses to fire the surly new assistant (Evan Peters). Meanwhile, Andy (Ed Helms) acts as if he doesn't mind that Erin (Ellie Kemper) has expressed interest in another man. And Pam (Jenna Fischer) thinks she'll impress Jim (John Krasinski) with a prank of her own. She could be wrong. 9 A.M. (ABC) LIVE WITH REGIS AND KELLY Johnny Weir swaps his figure skates for a pair of stilettos to run in the men's division of the ''High Heel-a-thon,'' a 150-yard dash in Central Park held on Tuesday -- in heels three inches or more -- to support the Foundation for the National Institutes of Health.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Microsoft officially released a beta version of Internet Explorer 9, the latest remake of the company's nearly-ubiquitous Web browser. A few months from now, it will become the built-in browser on all new PCs. Most techies think of Internet Explorer as the first piece of software they replace on a new computer. Firefox, Chrome, Safari and Opera are the preferred browser brands among self-styled geeks. But IE9, as everyone calls it, has some features of its own that make it worth a test drive.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to capitalize on the popularity of social networking, the well-known venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is teaming up with heavyweights of the social Web to create a $250 million fund to invest in social start-ups. The ''sFund'' was announced by John Doerr, a Kleiner veteran, on Thursday at a star-studded press conference at Facebook headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif. The fund includes investments from Amazon, Facebook, the Zynga Gaming Network, Comcast, Liberty Media and Allen & Company, as well as Kleiner and some unnamed individuals. The chief executives of Amazon, Facebook and Zynga -- Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and Mark Pincus -- all spoke at the event. They declined to say how much each party put into the fund.

I have no doubt that the company is seriously committed to the environment; as Apple notes on its Web site, every one of its products meets or exceeds Energy Star standards. But one of its products needs some work in the green department: MobileMe. The software that keeps the contacts and calendars stored on your computers, iPad, and iPhone in sync comes in a cute cardboard box. Actually, the software doesn't come in the box; you download that directly from the Apple Web site. What actually comes in the box is...virtually nothing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost 20 years ago, when I was reporting on the then-emerging field of microfinance (now a $25 billion industry), I discovered that different people would often look at the same set of facts and come to opposite conclusions about whether they revealed something positive or negative. At the time, most of the funding for microloans came from foreign aid and philanthropy, and no lenders had yet turned profits. For some business-minded people, this was awful. It demonstrated that microfinance was an illegitimate kind of banking, worse ─ a form of charity. For those who were socially concerned, it was a saving grace. If microfinance ever became highly profitable, they feared, it would attract the wrong kind of people ─ profit-seekers ─ who would ultimately abandon the poor.

docs.lead_paragraph: Wednesday, Oct. 27 Life is tough for tropical mammalogists. They work on a group with a limited number of species, maybe 150 at places like the ones we are in, and most of those species are bats and rats. Other than monkeys, most of the large mammals in the Amazon are rare. To detect them, mammalogists look for signs - scat, tracks, scratch marks, anything to let them know that a species is here. Worse, they have yahoo ornithologists reporting weird bats, and clueless botanists seeing rare deer. But they have to follow up on these reports. They also have to work night and day. Some mammals (monkeys, for example) are out in daylight hours, but for most, nighttime is when they are active.

docs.lead_paragraph: There was a party of dudes from Montana sitting at a table in Vij's in Vancouver, British Columbia, getting ready to graze. They were businessmen, in the city for a conference, and the hotel had sent them out to South Granville Street to wait for a table, for Vij's takes no reservations and never has. The men sat in the bar and had a few beers, and after a table opened they took it and looked at the menu and ordered, each of them asking for a variation on the same theme: some mutton kebabs to start, the beef tenderloin after; the mutton kebabs to start, the lamb Popsicles after.

docs.lead_paragraph: In Switzerland, a sans-serif, politely modern, supersleek, always tidy, adamantly neutral country, where everything uniformly ticktocks, lock-step, you might begin to think each new building and interior were designed by the same architect. Switzerland even has a typeface -- Helvetica -- named after it (the country is also known as Confoederatio Helvetica), in which no letter steps out of line. But an eBay purchase led me to Zurich, where I found the serif, the dingbat and the curvy character, all in one: Arthur Rooks. I bought a primitive spindle-back farm chair for peanuts, which Rooks, the invisible seller at the other end of my eBay transaction, claimed was hand-carved, 150 years old and straight from the ferme in Belfort, France, about an hour and a half across the border from Zurich. I PayPal-ed it, pronto, and Rooks shipped it to me meticulously cushioned and perfectly crated, in a matter of days, as if I'd just bought slippers at Zappos. It was exactly as described, and got me wondering, Who is this guy? With that stout, German-sounding name, I pictured a hardy hiker in lederhosen, surrounded by Alpine shipping-room elves. I discovered that Rooks also runs a home furnishings Web site, quintessentia.com, where you will find a treasure trove of seriously good stuff. He sells Bauhaus, Arts & Crafts, early Swiss Modernist and much better midcentury modern than you can find in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the end of 2008, I was part of an NYTimes.com team that took structured data sets from many aspects of The Times and centralized them into one data repository. One of my favorite projects was the integration of the New York Times Best Sellers data. We used a PHP framework - later open-sourced as NYT_Transformer - to process the best-seller data. Then we built an API on top of that data, using our open-source DBSlayer tool. In early 2009, we released the Best Sellers API to the developer community.

docs.lead_paragraph: The 30-year-old chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, is the newest member of tech's most exclusive club: entrepreneurs who walked away from multibillion-dollar takeover offers. On Friday, Mr. Mason rejected Google's $6 billion bid, according to two people with direct knowledge of the situation. The move quashed the search giant's hope of buying the fast-growing social buying site and put Groupon on track for an eventual public offering. Whether his gamble is a brilliant play or a Friendster fumble - the once promising social network that tumbled after snubbing an offer from Google - remains to be seen. For now, Mr. Mason, who is currently juggling television appearances and managing a recent spike in traffic, seems content with Groupon's trajectory. Mr. Mason spoke with DealBook on Wednesday about his company's prospects, the opportunities in the local advertising market, and why he likes dollhouses. Q.How was Friday? A.What happened on Friday? Haha Friday was a good day.

docs.lead_paragraph: PARIS -- For many Europeans, Washington's fierce reaction to the flood of secret diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks displays imperial arrogance and hypocrisy, indicating a post-9/11 obsession with secrecy that contradicts American principles. While the Obama administration has done nothing in the courts to block the publication of any of the leaked documents, or even, as of yet, tried to indict the WikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange, for any crime, American officials and politicians have been widely condemned in the European news media for calling the leaks everything from ''terrorism'' (Representative Peter T. King, Republican of New York) to ''an attack against the international community'' (Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton). Secretary of Defense Robert M. Gates called the arrest of Mr. Assange on separate rape charges ''good news.'' Sarah Palin called for him to be hunted as an ''anti-American operative with blood on his hands,'' and Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor and Republican presidential candidate, said that whoever leaked the cables should be executed.

headline.main: Many Europeans Find U.S. Attacks on WikiLeaks Puzzling

docs.abstract: Many Europeans find that Washington's fierce reaction to flood of secret cables released by Wikileaks displays imperial arrogance and hypocrisy and an obsession with secrecy that contradicts American principles (M)

Trudy Muller, an Apple spokeswoman, said the company had removed the app ''because it violated our developer guidelines.'' Ms. Muller added: ''Apps must comply with all local laws and may not put an individual or group in harm's way.''

docs.lead_paragraph: BEIJING -- Star-crossed love between Alexander the Great and his teenage male slave. Ferocious battles that defined an empire. The bloodshed and romance of Ancient Greece. The novel ''The Persian Boy,'' by Mary Renault, has it all. In the West, the book, which is filled with scenes of pederasty and homosexual passion, raises a few eyebrows nearly four decades after it was first published. But in China, where omnipotent censors regularly smother sensitive content and portrayals of sexuality are illegal, one would think a book like this would never make it to the bookstore shelf, let alone past a publisher's desk.

headline.main: Increasing Demand From China's Readers Helps Create a More Open Industry
